awd_titl_txt: Development of a Wide-Field Transient Absorption Microscope for Applications to Two-Dimensional Perovskite Quantum Wells
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Experimental Physics Program (AMO-E) in the Division of Physics, Professor Moran at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, is developing a microscope capable of imaging electron movement in perovskite crystals. This work is motivated by the potential for solar energy harvesting demonstrated by perovksites. The perovskite crystals targeted in this project have two-dimensional (2D) shapes where the faces of the crystals have millimeter-scale dimensions. Such 2D perovskites absorb light in the visible range and are relatively resistant to humidity, which is desirable for harnessing solar energy.  Professor Moran and his team plan to simultaneously monitor multiple places on the crystal surface to get statistical information on electron movement in the crystals. The information from these experiments can be used to guide material synthesis to make better solar energy conversion devices. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project become proficient in chemistry, computer programming, machining, electronics, and optics as the research group  is building most of their own equipment. In addition, Professor Moran and his students supervise laboratory exercises that illustrate the principles of optics and solar cells for middle and high-school students in collaboration with the Morehead Planetarium on the UNC campus.

Professor Moran at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill is developing a diffractive optic-based transient absorption microscope capable of imaging electron diffusion in two-dimensional (2D) perovskite quantum wells. The quantum wells targeted have garnered attention for their stabilities under humid conditions and large exciton binding energies. In addition, the research team is investigating layered systems that consist of "stacks" of quantum wells in which the band gap decreases with respect to height in the film. Thus, electronic excitations are funneled from the bottom to the top of the film in these layered perovskites.  The diffractive optic-based microscope employed in this research acquires transient absorption data at 41 locations on the sample surface in a single experiment. Signals are simultaneously detected at two probe wavelengths using a pair of array detectors (e.g., wavelengths corresponding to energy donor and acceptor quantum wells). In studies of exfoliated crystals, diffusivities of excitons are being measured at a number of excitation wavelengths to establish a quantitative relationship between the carrier diffusivity and excitation energy. Statistical distributions of diffusion rates are generated by analyzing the dynamics at 41 different spots on the sample. The information derived from these experiments can be used to guide materials synthesis and device engineering. Graduate and undergraduate students becoming proficient in computer programming, machining, electronics, and optics as the research group is building most of their own equipment.

por.por_cntn:
Perovskite materials consisting of metal halide and molecular components absorb light and transport electrons with high efficiencies, which is beneficial for optoelectronic applications including light-emitting diodes and photovoltaic cells. Knowledge of charge transport mechanisms in perovskites is essential for their characterization and development; however, the mobilities of photoexcited species are often determined in films prepared outside of devices using conventional laser spectroscopies. Although valuable insights are derived from ex-situ experimental approaches, implications of the observations for a device’s operation mechanisms can be ambiguous. For instance, the signals measured in conventional laser spectroscopy experiments generally reflect the concentrations and absorptivities of all photoexcited species in a material regardless of functional relevance. This is a particular problem for perovskites due to the coexistence of free and bound charges generated by light absorption.

 

In this project, the team initially developed a diffractive optic-based transient absorption microscope in which the diffusion of photoexcited species in perovskite films was imaged over a wide area using a grid of 41 laser beams. These measurements revealed that the carrier diffusivities associated with solution-processed films are 10-100 times smaller than those of the corresponding crystalline materials. To eliminate ambiguities related to the functionalities of devices, the team later developed “action spectroscopy” techniques in which the electric current generated by a solar cell is directly detected in response to a sequence of laser pulses. Because bound charges (i.e., excitons) do not contribute to the photocurrent, the action spectroscopies were able to demonstrate that free charge carriers are readily trapped at interfaces between molecules and lead iodide quantum wells in layered perovskite materials, where organic and inorganic sheets are assembled in an alternating manner. With inspiration from optical pump-probe methods, electron velocities were also measured in various perovskite systems with ~100-picosecond time resolution by applying a sequence of two laser pulses to a photovoltaic device. The team showed that electron velocities generally increase with the thicknesses of “quantum wells” in layered perovskite systems.

 

The results of this project have been disseminated in more than 10 publications in peer-reviewed journals. Graduate students involved in this project developed technical skills related to lasers, optics, electronics, machining, and computer programming. Several students who worked on this project and have since graduated are now engineers at companies specializing in optics, spectroscopy, and chemical processing. The team contributed solar cells demonstrations for an annual science fair at Morehead planetarium on the campus of the University of North Carolina. In addition, a user-friendly program for computing pi orbitals in conjugated organic molecules was developed and made publicly accessible.
